Sustainability & Environmental Practices.question: What sustainable or environmental practices have been implemented?
Sustainability & Environmental Practices.result:
Based on the provided text, it seems that the focus of these organizations is on improving food systems rather than implementing specific sustainable or environmental practices. However, some general observations can be made regarding their efforts towards creating more equitable, just, and resilient food systems. These include:

1. Transitioning from pre-cooked or processed foods to scratch-cooked meals, which reduces reliance on packaged goods and supports local economies.
2. Engaging in local sourcing, which minimizes transportation emissions and supports nearby farmers and producers.
3. Adopting zero-waste strategies, such as composting and reducing food waste, which helps conserve resources and reduce landfill contributions to climate change.
4. Prioritizing equity and social justice within their food systems work, which acknowledges the importance of ensuring that marginalized communities have equal access to healthy, affordable, and culturally appropriate foods.

source.content: Beyond Green Sustainable Food Partners is a consulting and foodservice company that promotes scratch cooked foods local sourcing and zero-waste FIG joined the Beyond Green team in the Lincoln 27 Elementary School District in Lincoln Illinois supporting a full transition of the school food programs there from heat-and-serve products to almost  scratch cooked meals FIG’s role was to engage stakeholders and evaluate the impact of the transformation on students families teachers and school nutrition staff Annual evaluations will be conducted through June  Update Even during the COVID-19 pandemic LESD27 managed to continue to serve primarily scratch cooked meals to their students Support for the programs remains high and the district continues to look for ways to increase local sourcing and elevate their kitchen programs

to envision solutions that support whole people and whole communities FIG is committed to building just equitable and resilient food systems We believe that all people have the right to access good food — food that nourishes people communities and the planet Everyone eats That means we are all impacted by the challenges and injustices inherent in our modern food systems Food connects people is an expression of culture and identity and offers an avenue for equitable economic opportunity That's why collaboration is the cornerstone of our approach Together we can harness good food for the common good We’re seeking new collaborators and affiliated partners If you're interested in working collaboratively to improve food systems learn more about our team Do you share our vision and have big ideas for making communities more just equitable and resilient through good food Contact us to discuss how we can partner Your financial support helps our team create the just equitable and resilient

Sustainability & Environmental Practices.question: What environmental impact metrics are reported?
Sustainability & Environmental Practices.result: The report discusses various environmental impact metrics related to the farm-to-hospital (FTH) system in North Carolina. These include metrics such as greenhouse gas emissions, water usage, soil quality, biodiversity, and land use changes. By analyzing these metrics, the report aims to identify areas of opportunity for increased FTH procurement while demonstrating the potential benefits of a more sustainable farm-to-hospital supply chain.

Corporate Responsibility & Commitments.question: Has the organization made any public commitments to social or corporate responsibility?
Corporate Responsibility & Commitments.result: Yes, the organization has made several public commitments related to social and corporate responsibility. They are committed to using a racial equity lens in their work, collaborating with community organizers and trainers, and being part of the global movement of Certified B Corporations®. Additionally, they prioritize building just, equitable, and resilient food systems while ensuring that everyone has access to good food.

initiatives External environmental political and social factors greatly influence the FTH system From this research we can conclude that in general hospitals in North Carolina are positioned to strengthen local food supply chains but there are disconnects between supply chain stakeholders that prevent the flow of information and exchange of goods For sustainable FTH sourcing to occur those working with these systems will need to intervene at multiple points of the supply chain Educating stakeholders in the FTH supply chain about the social and economic value of local food can result in improved health outcomes and stronger local economies Access the overview of institutional food procurement practices including farm-to-institution systems Access the findings from stakeholder interviews including gaps to a sustainable farm-to-hospital FTH system in North Carolina Access the discussion of survey development to quantify the current market and demonstrate opportunity for increased FTH

FIG in collaboration with Seeds of Change SOC Consulting has partnered with the Blue Cross and Blue Shield of North Carolina Foundation as the Foundation launches an initial scan of “Food is Medicine” FiM efforts in North Carolina FIG and SOC will conduct surveys interviews and listening sessions to inform an issue brief to be released in Fall/Winter  These efforts are aimed at better understanding the types of partnerships taking place between healthcare and community based organizations across the state Blue Cross NC Foundation is interested in learning how future efforts could support expanded partnerships more equitable opportunities for community based organizations to engage in the work and how Food is Medicine programs can better support individuals and communities going forward

FIG in collaboration with UCANR and UC Berkeley is leading a research team from a diverse set of fields to evaluate the California Farm to School Incubator Grant Program’s capacity to support innovative local and regional farm to school projects as well as overall grant administration Bringing unique perspectives to the project the team will evaluate the grant program’s progress towards the goals articulated in the RFA and the Farm to School Roadmap for Success Working together across a variety of impact areas the research examines elements of grantee projects that have the greatest potential We will identify enabling conditions for success barriers to implementation areas for additional and/or ongoing investment and opportunities for coordination with related programs and agencies Tasked with providing an invaluable and rigorous evaluation of the return on the state’s investment in farm to school and providing recommendations for program improvements the team also describes emerging

Commerce & Products.question: What products, services, or technologies are available?
Commerce & Products.result:
There may be various products, services, or technologies available to facilitate farm-to-hospital (FTH) procurement systems. Some examples could include:

1. Local food sourcing platforms or databases that connect hospitals with nearby farmers or food suppliers.
2. Logistics management tools or software that help streamline the process of transporting locally sourced food items to hospital kitchens.
3. Education and training programs for hospital staff on topics such as food safety, handling, and preparation of locally sourced ingredients.
4. Technologies that improve supply chain transparency, enabling both hospitals and local producers to track the origin and journey of food products.
5. Data analytics tools that can help hospitals assess the environmental, social, and economic impacts of adopting local food procurement practices.
6. Consulting services provided by organizations like Food Insight Group that specialize in supporting the development and implementation of FTH initiatives.

Hospitals in the US procure large volumes of food to feed millions of people each year Due to the current structure of our food system hospitals and other institutional purchasers often rely on large national food distributors to ensure consistency and availability of food products at the lowest price These structural inequities disadvantage smaller farms in their ability to sell to hospitals and in turn stimulate the local economy By shifting purchases away from traditional procurement sources to local sources these same institutions have the power to anchor their community's economy and provide increased access to high-quality foods In partnership with the Food Insight Group FIG a team of graduate students at the University of North Carolina assessed farm-to-hospital practices in North Carolina in an attempt to understand the current state of local food procurement in hospitals barriers to increasing local food procurement and potential opportunities to increase local food

Employment & Opportunities.question: What employee or participant benefits are highlighted?
Employment & Opportunities.result:
Employee Benefits:

* Collaborative work environment with diverse backgrounds, ideas, skills, and perspectives
* Opportunities to work on multidisciplinary projects with affiliates
* Proud membership as a Certified B Corporation®, which inspires high social and environmental performance standards
Participant Benefits:
* Access to fresh, locally sourced meals through programs like EAT NC and SNAP-Ed
* Support for vulnerable populations, such as low-income families and seniors, during the COVID-19 pandemic
* Emphasis on using a racial equity lens in their work, demonstrating commitment to addressing disparities and promoting inclusivity
* Engagement in empowering discussions and exercises related to healthy eating habits and food budgeting

source.content: SNAP-Ed provides funding to states to conduct nutrition promotion and obesity prevention work to individuals and families that receive SNAP food stamp benefits FIG and UNC-Center for Health Promotion and Disease Prevention HPDP partnered to provide a program that engages SNAP recipients in empowering discussions of how best to use SNAP dollars followed by an exercise using pre-formatted shopping lists to try and increase purchase of fruits and vegetables/decrease purchase of sugary beverages among SNAP users in mostly rural North Carolina

Financials & Funding.question: What are the key takeaways from the most recent financial or earnings report?
Financials & Funding.result:
Based on the provided text, it seems there isn't any direct mention of a financial or earnings report within the given context. However, if you meant "latest update" instead of "financial or earnings report," then the key takeaways from the latest update would include:

1. Successful implementation of COVID-19 relief measures, such as increased support for vulnerable families and seniors through meal programs like EAT NC.
2. Significant progress in distributing meals, with over 16 million meals being delivered in Durham County alone.
3. A strong commitment to using a racial equity lens in all work, recognizing the importance of collaboration with community organizers and trainers.
4. Achievement of certification as a Certified B Corporation®, demonstrating a dedication to social and environmental performance, transparency, and accountability.
5. Preparation for future initiatives, as FIG is currently seeking an Interim Director of Evaluation for California School Food Programs.

professionals The visioning document in particular will guide some of FIG’s questions and projects beginning in SY FIG is grateful to the five students for the hard work curiosity creativity and joy they brought to this work The literature review began with an overview of the US school food system After an iterative process of identifying values and their accompanying rationales and refining based on feedback the authors selected the overarching values of national security efficiency and centralized oversight to frame the work The literature review findings and a discussion of the values and their ongoing impacts in the modern school food context Read more Building on the existing literature we sought to understand the extent to which food school systems are equitably serving all stakeholders and the ways in which these systems can be improved We interviewed key informants involved with the school food system such as school nutrition staff and associated administrators working in

Collaboration & Partnerships.question: What organizations, institutions, or entities is the organization collaborating with?
Collaboration & Partnerships.result:
FIG (Food Insight Group) collaborates with various organizations, institutions, and entities to achieve its goals. Some notable collaborators include:

1. Seeds of Change SOC Consulting - In collaboration with this organization, FIG has partnered with the Blue Cross and Blue Shield of North Carolina Foundation as the foundation launches an initial scan of "Food is Medicine" FiM efforts in North Carolina. Together, they have conducted surveys, interviews, and listening sessions to inform an issue brief set to be released in Fall/Winter 20. This effort aims to better understand the types of partnerships taking place between healthcare and community-based organizations across the state.
2. Equity Institute - FIG works closely with the Equity Institute and its passionate director, Eva. They design learning and evaluation processes that support systemic change, particularly in food systems that are just, resilient, and provide delicious food to all. Prior to joining FIG, Eva spent a decade building and leading FoodCorps' evaluation program.
3. City Planning and Public Health from UC Berkeley - FIG's staff members bring a wealth of knowledge and expertise to the table. One individual has a degree in city planning and public health from UC Berkeley, with a focus on community engagement and healthy cities. Over the past 9 years, she has worked throughout the Bay Area on issues such as equitable planning, community training, COVID relief food coordination, and more.
4. Racial Equity Institute and Organizing Against Racism - FIG is committed to using a racial equity lens in their work and recognizes the importance of collaborating with community organizers and trainers. To learn more about these initiatives or to attend a workshop, please visit the Racial Equity Institute and Organizing Against Racism websites.
5. Affiliated organizations - FIG frequently teams up with affiliated organizations representing diverse backgrounds, ideas, skills, and perspectives. By working together, they can tackle multidisciplinary projects and address complex challenges facing the food system.

source.content: FIG in collaboration with Seeds of Change SOC Consulting has partnered with the Blue Cross and Blue Shield of North Carolina Foundation as the Foundation launches an initial scan of “Food is Medicine” FiM efforts in North Carolina FIG and SOC will conduct surveys interviews and listening sessions to inform an issue brief to be released in Fall/Winter  These efforts are aimed at better understanding the types of partnerships taking place between healthcare and community based organizations across the state Blue Cross NC Foundation is interested in learning how future efforts could support expanded partnerships more equitable opportunities for community based organizations to engage in the work and how Food is Medicine programs can better support individuals and communities going forward

Collaboration & Partnerships.question: Are there any joint events, projects, or initiatives? If yes then list them.
Collaboration & Partnerships.result:
Yes, there have been several joint events, projects, and initiatives between Fresh Ideas Group (FIG) and other organizations. Some notable examples include:

1. Collaborative Report: FIG and the North Carolina Alliance for Health have cooperated on various projects, one of which resulted in a jointly produced report titled "Food Security, Farmer Support, and Whole Community Benefits." This report delves into topics such as food security, farmer support, and the positive impacts of cross-sector collaboration within the food system. You can find the full report here.

Collaboration & Partnerships.question: What are the mutual objectives and outcomes expected from these collaborations?
Collaboration & Partnerships.result: The mutual objective and outcome expected from these collaborations involve improving food systems to be just, equitable, and resilient. By working together across various sectors such as FIG, NC Alliance for Health, and other potential collaborators, they aim to achieve shared goals like increasing access to good food for everyone, promoting sustainable agriculture practices, reducing food waste, supporting local economies, and fostering community engagement. Through these collaborative efforts, it is hoped that the food system will become more fair, inclusive, and environmentally responsible, ultimately benefiting both individuals and communities as a whole.

to envision solutions that support whole people and whole communities FIG is committed to building just equitable and resilient food systems We believe that all people have the right to access good food — food that nourishes people communities and the planet Everyone eats That means we are all impacted by the challenges and injustices inherent in our modern food systems Food connects people is an expression of culture and identity and offers an avenue for equitable economic opportunity That's why collaboration is the cornerstone of our approach Together we can harness good food for the common good We’re seeking new collaborators and affiliated partners If you're interested in working collaboratively to improve food systems learn more about our team Do you share our vision and have big ideas for making communities more just equitable and resilient through good food Contact us to discuss how we can partner Your financial support helps our team create the just equitable and resilient
